bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, February 13, 1918

div1.p: Gorgas writes that he favors combining the U.S. Public Health Service and the War Department. Gorgas does not know if he will be retained after his retirement, although he looks forward to resuming yellow fever work after war.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, February 13, 1918
div1.opener:
WCG/HHW
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
February 13,1918.
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
Assistant-Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service,
Marine Hospital, Baltimore - Maryland.
My dear Carter:
div1.p:
Yours of February the seventh is acknowledged.
There is a movement on foot to consolidate our two services.
I could use to advantage the personnel of the Public Health
Service in the extra-cantonment work, and work similar to that
if I had also the function of the Public Health Service; but
to bring your personnel over, without their functions, would
not be of very great service to us.

The principal reason, however, for my favoring this scheme
is, that it would put us in an advantageous position after the
war is over for a more extensive Public Health Service than we
had before the war. By that time, however, I hope to be out
of it as a personal equasion.

I have had no intimation as to whether I am to be retained
after October the 3rd, the date when I retire by statute, or not.
I am ready to serve anywhere in any capacity until the war is
over. How, or where I serve, is the Secretary's business, not
mine, and I am glad I have nothing to do with the decision.

I get most interesting letters from Guiteras; he has been
sick lately and Dr. Rose, yesterday afternoon told me that he was

going back to Cuba for a time. I look forward with
a great deal of anticipation to getting into this work
just as soon as the war is over.
Mrs. Gorgas joins me in kindest regards.
